ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about how to track down recent innovations in the scientific literature, along with the previous research on which they were based, as well as how to summarize that literature relatively succinctly.
Learned how to read literature and construct and argument independently
I learned how to define an appropriate topic for a literature review and how to write a literature review.
I learned how to evaluate scientific literature and write a review paper.
I was able to synthesize papers, my research in the lab, and think critically about the topic of my paper.
I developed my ability to review the literature for recent developments in a particular field.
I learned how to perform a literature review on a topic and be able to synthesize information from various sources into a cohesive paper.
I learned how to identify an interesting scientific problem, find important literature surrounding the topic, and present the current state of the field.
Writing a term-long paper
I learned about viral replication and how to write a lit review!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class's greatest strength is the intense scaffolding which the intermediate deadlines provide, ensuring that students are never overwhelmed by an avalance of work for which they were not prepared. The oppurtunity to come together for the sessions at the beginning and the end also allowed for a real feeling of cameraderie among all seniors in the department. However, the actual implementation of the course logistics was in many cases disastrous: key information was lost or communicated improperly; feedback was late, nonspecific, and ambiguous; and even basic mechanisms of finalizing graded work were often simply broken.

Strengths - advisor was helpful
Weaknesses - maybe more specifications would be helpful

Strengths: Having deadlines along the way was really helpful for keeping me on track throughout the semester, so I didn't have to cram everything in at the end and had time to implement feedback. My instructor was very prompt in giving feedback and was very helpful with the literature review and the poster design. 

Weaknesses: None, I actually found this to be a pretty low-stress senior project as far as senior projects go.
Feedback could be given in a more timely manner and in more depth, but I appreciated the enthusiasm the support provided by our advisors. Thank you!
I think the course is an excellent capstone to the MB&B major. However, I had never written a review paper before so it was a struggle for me.

Strengths-my advisor was knowledgeable in my topic of interest and was able to help me think through it.

Weaknesses-I know I was lucky, but several of my classmates did not have professors who knew much about their topic of interest. However, as successful scientists, I do not think it is actually that important for the advisor to know students topic of interest welljust need to know how to write a literature review!
More active engagement throughout the semester- meetings with advisors needs to be structured and much more frequent.

It's not a lot of work, which is certainly a plus but also leaves me wondering why the course even exists... I had very limited interactions with my faculty advisor for the course and it didn't feel like I was really learning much, nor did I get the sense that anyone cared about my finished product. The communication for the poster/flash talks at the end was also quite poor (I didn't know the size/style parameters until about a week before it was due, and they never actually conveyed what the poster was supposed to be about!).
The course is very hands-off which could be either a strength or a weakness depending on the student.

The strengths of the course were that you could choose any topic of interest. The weakness was that there was very little guidance throughout the semester on how to write an effective review paper. Additionally, there was very little feedback given on our drafts which made it difficult to know what we could do to improve.
It was a great course and gave room for feedback. I liked the mini deadlines throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Whether or not a student should take this course depends on the extent to which they are capable of writing in order to fulfill a requirement. Students who can take any topic and write any amount on that topic for a grade should have no trouble in this class, while those who need some spark of interest in the content of a paper will likely struggle.
Yes because it is required

Yes! You have to take this for the MB&B major, but I actually did find the process of writing a literature review and making/presenting the poster to be quite rewarding. You have ample time (a whole semester) to do everything, and all the instructors seemed to be very kind, understanding, and willing to help in any way possible.
This is a required course to graduate with an MBB major.
It's a requirement for the major.
It is a required course, wouldn't really recommend otherwise.
You have to take it for MB&B
